author: Nicola Agius
title: Terry Pratchett: Back in Black documentary leaves fans in tears: 'He'll always be missed'
text:
Terry Pratchett: Back in Black left fans in tears this evening. 
Viewers watching the BBC Two documentary, which gave the nation a rare glimpse into the legendary author's life, were touched by the emotionally charged scenes. 
Afterwards, those who had watched the 50 minute programme had nothing but praise for it, admitting it was a fitting tribute for the writer, who passed away two years ago. 
"I'm 30 seconds into the Terry Pratchett documentary from tonight and I'm close to tears already. His work is still hugely important to me," one fan gushed on Twitter. Terry Pratchett: Back in Black left fans in tears (Photo: PA) 
Another then posted: "What a fascinating insight to Terry Pratchett this programme was. Made me laugh, cry & think ... not necessarily in that order. #BackInBlack." 
Moments later, a different viewer commented: "Beautiful programme on Sir Terry Pratchett, that most incredible of human beings. I maintain he was every bit as good as Austen or Dickens." Read More 
Shortly afterwards, another wrote: "'Back in Black' is a beautiful documentary about Terry Pratchett. A brilliant writer. He'll always be missed." 
Sir Terry died aged 66, after a public struggle with Alzheimer's . 
He had been working on his own life story before he died in 2015, but the devastating disease meant that he was not able to finish it. Read More Author Terry Pratchett 'left £11.4million in his will' following battle with Alzheimer’s 
But those close to him were able to step in and complete the BBC documentary Terry Pratchett: Back In Black, telling writer's story in his own words, with comedian and actor Paul Kaye voicing the writer. Viewers watching the BBC Two documentary, which gave the nation a rare glimpse into the legendary author's life, were touched by the emotionally charged scenes (Photo: PA) 
Sir Terry's books sold millions of copies worldwide and were translated into more than 30 languages. 
He completed his last book - set like so many of his best-sellers in Discworld - a year before his death. 
Towards the end of his life, he used his fame and wealth to campaign for a greater awareness of dementia and assisted dying. Sir Terry died aged 66, after a public struggle with Alzheimer's in 2015 (Photo: Getty) 
Mark Bell, head of commissioning for BBC Arts, said: "Terry wanted to effectively write the story of his life as a writer but he never got around to it because his bad health intervened. 
"This was an attempt to say, here's a way of bringing his life as a writer to life. We got Paul Kaye to say Terry's words. It's quite bold and the family saw it and were moved I think. It's a sweet film." Like us on Facebook
